chapter.title: Federal laws affecting adults with LD
chapter.content:
Federal laws affecting adults with LD

Our first guiding question asks:

Which federal laws affect adults with LD?

Let’s begin by discussing three such laws.

chapter.title: Three federal laws affecting adults with LD have similarities and differences
chapter.content:
Three federal laws affecting adults with LD have similarities and differences

Three federal laws affect adults with LD:

  • the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), most recently reauthorized in 2004;
  • the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (also known as the Rehab Act); and
  • the Americans With Disabilities Act Amendments Act (ADAAA), 2008.

[NOTE: The Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) was amended in 2008 and is now referred to as the ADAAA. It is sometimes still referred to as the ADA.]

These three laws have similarities and differences. We will briefly examine important parts of these laws to improve your understanding of how individuals with LD can better advocate for their needs and accommodations.

chapter.title: Major Provisions of IDEA, Rehab Act, and ADAAA
chapter.content:
Major Provisions of IDEA, Rehab Act, and ADAAA

This chart provides a brief overview of the three federal laws that affect adults with LD. Only the Rehab Act and ADAAA apply directly to the needs of adults with a specific learning disability. Take a moment to review the chart to familiarize yourself with the major provisions of each law before moving on.

IDEA Rehab Act ADAAA
  • Individualized education programs (IEPs)
  • Provides for free and appropriate education
  • Protects the rights of parents and children with disabilities
  • Has least restrictive environment
  • Allows states to receive federal funds to provide special education services
  • Civil rights law
  • Makes discrimination unlawful in federally funded employment and activities (including schools)
  • Provides limited funding to state rehabilitation agencies
  • Civil rights law
  • Extends Section 504 of the Rehab Act
  • Prohibits discrimination against the disabled in all aspects of society
  • Provides no funding
